qas.question: What kind of containers are used for bottle conditioned beers?
What do bottle conditioned beers contain that most fears do not?
What ingredient is filtered out of most beers when it is packaged in bottles and cans?
What are the recommendations for pouring bottle conditioned beers?
What type of bottle conditioned beer is customarily poured with the yeast in it?
Filtering clears all beers of what?
Where is yeast left when serving a hefeweizen wheet beer?
What happens to 9% of the contents of a hefeweizen?

context: Most beers are cleared of <b5_0>yeast<b5_0/> by filtering when packaged in bottles and cans. However, bottle conditioned beers retain some <a1_0><a2_0>yeast<a2_0/><a1_0/>—either by being unfiltered, or by being filtered and then reseeded with fresh yeast. It is usually recommended that the beer be poured <a3_0>slowly<a3_0/>, leaving any yeast sediment at the <b6_0>bottom of the bottle<b6_0/>. However, some drinkers prefer to pour in the yeast; this practice is customary with <a4_0>wheat beers<a4_0/>. Typically, when serving a hefeweizen wheat beer, 90% of the <b7_0>contents are poured<b7_0/>, and the remainder is swirled to suspend the sediment before pouring it into the glass. Alternatively, the bottle may be inverted prior to opening. <a0_0>Glass bottles<a0_0/> are always used for bottle conditioned beers.
